column4: hi guys, is there a command in the terminal wherein you can "unlock" the users and groups in the System>Administration>User and Groups ??
only the 'sudo  allowed/administrator' user can unloock that.  if you want other users to have the rights they need to also be in the admin group i belive
i've already added a user into the admin group "adduser <user> admin"..but it still cannot "unlock" the users and group
logout/back in as that user.
there is no magical command. You have to be in the right group for it to work.
can your user  use 'sudo' at all?
thanks
yes, it can use sudo
that is weird then.   You could try 'gksudo users-admin'
it prompts the users settings, but it displays Gtk-WARNING on the terminal, its about 12 lines of WARNING and CRITICAL on the last line
so the program shows?or  dosent show?
the program shows...the User Settings
the weird thing is, it doesnt ask for authentication when i opened the users settings using the panels
or learn to admin users as root via the command line.. You did try that 'gksudo users-admin' command.. if that dident work.. then somthing is very broken.
is it with the package?
i mean the "broken" thing
no idea on that.  but somthing is weird.
theres proberly things to try.. but those may be a bit insecure..
i normally just admin my  users via the command line.. but  i only have 3 users. :)
i have 2 users on the admin group but both of them cant execute the "unlock"
yep. somthing is weird there.
